Hi Lars,

I've taken a look and it's looking good.

I think there's been a bit of confusion around which categories we are using though.

The category list I have is - 

•	Construction & Venues
•	Sports
•	Culture, Ceremonies & Torch Relay
•	Business
•	Round the UK
•	Education

Can we implement this, and then let me know if there is an issue around compatibility.

I think we were expecting there to be an extra meta-data tag which we would need to fill in.
This sounds like a lot of work for somebody re-entering metadata on old news stories! Let's discuss it on Monday.

Hi Tom (+Danny and Lars)

We just need to add the new tags to the Theme taxonomy.
https://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/coder/_system/taxonomy/themes.xml

I was just about to do this but released (with the values below) that there is a question around whether we are in danger of mixing up navigation labels and tags ie. is "Culture, Ceremonies & Torch Relay" really a tag or a grouping of tags? I think we should be tagging articles to Culture, Ceremonies and/or Torch Relay and if we need to group them in the navigation then do that there. Is 'Round the UK' really a tag, or just a grouping for articles that don't fit into any of the above categories?

Just to clarify, tthe reason we are re-using the 'Theme' taxonomy is that, that is the taxonomy also used by other pages on the site including Photos, Videos etc. so if we want related images and videos to tie in with News and Blog pages it doent' make sense to have two taxonomies / tags (unless you want to also re-tag all the photos and videos)

The one danger / issue here is where we have News articles that are already tagged to the theme Taxonomy (as obv. we are not differentiating between the new tags and the existing ones).

In terms of tagging existing articles, you will need to re-tag News/Blog articles if you want a tag driven navigation, although you probably only need to tag up enough recent articles to fill the navigation (the older articles will still appear under month/year). 

Let me know your thoughts, as obviously it would be good to get this piece of work live.

Jamie

Hi Jamie,

Are you free to take a call this afternoon.

I think it would be good to chat about this properly as after a meeting last week it seems there are a few things to work through.

Thanks,

Tom
Reassigned to Jamie, as a reminder to discuss this with Tom this week. We are aiming to return to this and complete it next week.

Hi Tom,

Just realised this is still open and we need to close it off.

My understanding is:

1) We need to set you up a new taxonomy 'News'

With these values?

• Construction & Venues
• Sports
• Culture, Ceremonies & Torch Relay
• Business
• Round the UK
• Education

2) You need to tag up some articles (we may be able to automate this based on other tags, but getting the last week or so News articles tag up would be good)

3) We then need to replace the current new hub.

Jamie

Hi Tom, 

Are you happy for us to put the new News hub live / are the tags above correct?

Jamie
Tom, I am quite keen to allocate the 5 days already spent on this to February's retainer--even though we haven't been able to deploy the code yet. Would this be acceptable?
Marking as solved with 5 days allocated to it, but please do feel free to re-open.

I am attaching this comment, while inviting Andy to join this thread.

Andy, a ramification of this ticket is that the current redirect behaviour for MOBILE user agents is changing as follows:

Currently: Any request for "index.php" is served a redirect to /mobile/. All other requests are served "as normal".

New behaviour: All requests are redirected to the associated MOBILE page (if it exists), else the "desktop" version is served.

I'm inviting you to this ticket in case you (or David) notice any changes to SEO behaviour, or in case you have any opinions on whether this will have any negative side-effects.

I intend to serve:
 301 Moved Permanently
accompanied by a "Vary: User-agent" header (which we don't currently serve; I am particularly interested in whether you feel we should serve this).

Please let me know if you have any questions. Soon, if possible, as this new behaviour is awaiting launch.

Thanks in advance,

Kieran

Andy

Similar functionality has been implemented on the /festival/ site, so it would be worth checking that there have been no SEO implications there before launching the behaviour on the www site.
Kieran

subject: Summary of luckit usage on london2012.com
description: As requested by Russ this morning.

comments.value: As requested by Russ this morning.

Context?

Is Russ simply interested in which pages have a search front end that users can type stuff into / page that return "search" results? or in pages that are built real-time via Luckit but where the use of Luckit is transparent to the user?

We use Luckit in all kinds of situations, we even use it internally in the CMS, so in order to answer the question correctly we probably need a bit more context.

Jamie, here's the context from Russ:

"We are doing some changes to limit the number of searches that users can do using an Akamai WAF feature. This is to protect the origin and the Luckit server from sustained hacks.
 
This feature  provides rate limiting to the http://www.london2012.com/search/index.htmx, to limit origin hits based on both average hits exceeding pre-set parameters, and burst hit exceeding pre-set parameters.

 The resulting action will put subsequent requests from the IP address triggering the rule, into a custom penalty box page. The look and feel of this area is be determined later - a std akamai page can be used for initial staging purposes.
 
I also see that we have a search function for photos:
 
www.london2012.com/photos/search
 
is this also on luckit and would we need to protect this too. 
 
Also have a search on the map too that goes straight to the origin.
 
Are there any other parts of the site that we would need to protect at all?"

As requested:


# The following is a mixture of "raw" paths (i.e. with a .php extension)
# and - where appropriate - the corresponding seo-friendly paths.

/about-us/publications/index.php
/about-us/publications
/games/sport-competition-schedules/paralympic-sport-competition-schedule.php
/paralympic-schedule
/games/sport-competition-schedules/olympic-sport-competition-schedule.php
/olympic-schedule
/young-leaders/index.php
/young-leaders
/young-leaders/meet/index.php
/young-leaders/meet 
/young-leaders/blog/index.php
/young-leaders/blog 
/photos/search.php
/news/search.php
/fr/photos/search.php
/fr/search.php
/fr/videos/recherche.php
/search.php
/videos/search.php
/get-involved/whats-on/past-events.php
/pastevents
/get-involved/business-network/future-procurement-opportunities/index.php
/get-involved/business-network/future-procurement-opportunities
/blog/search.php
/press/media-releases/search.php

# Note the following three paths have a "*" indicating a wildcard.
/get-involved/business-network/supplier-pages/*.php
/get-involved/business-network/oda-suppliers/sectors/*.php
/get-involved/business-network/oda-suppliers/contractors/*.php

# Note, in the following path, the letter "N" indicates a wildcard number (0-9).
/blog/20NN/NN/index.php

Internal note: I excluded the related-content stuff which DOES do a luckit search BUT the results are cached, once per section. While there might exist a theoretical possibility of a DOS attack against pages that include related content, I don't think we should draw attention to these pages as they're not really searches that the user knowingly instigates.

Thanks K,

Sounds like in this context (searching) the Akamai WAF is there primarily to stop site scraping via search results (although in LOOCG context that may not be an issue I imagine it is if you offer listing data that you don't want a competitor to copy ie. eBay or CraigsList).

Although they will want to be careful with genuine search engine spiders, who LOCOG may actually want to scrape the site, although well behaved spiders should respect sensible limits for concurrent/sequential requests. 

In terms of excessive rates / burst thresholding (as opposed to scraping prevention). I imagine the question is which uri's / requests will (a) go back to the origin and (b) put load on the server. I think Luckit is a slight red herring here, surely what is important is protecting *any* url that may be affected by excessive load or an unnatural burst of requests, for example the Torch Events page actually makes an API call back to Earthware. Yet on pages where we cache the output of a Luckit request the page will present no more load on Apache or Luckit than any other page.

Taking this further, surely 1000 requests from the same IP is suspect regardless of the url being hit, why even limit by url if we are going to turn on request throttling?

I guess that's a long way of saying:

"Why not apply the same moderate request rate thresholds across all pages? Why single out Luckit pages for throttling?"
"Or is scraping the issue? I'd suggest it isn't (or at least not in an eBay sense), surely we want to encourage spidering?"

Jamie
Marking as solved.

This is Boris from Akamai Ccare. For this configuration we are a) not ignoring the query string for png files and b) honoring origin cache control and expires headers.So we cache the png differently with any type of query string. Kirsten, we are sending "pragma: no-cache" deliberately. If you want to start caching pages, then we need to look at a strategy for doing so, as discussed some time ago (see http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/1254). We were intending to produce an outline plan of work for Huw Williams, but there has been no follow up since his departure. If you are still keen for us do do this work, then we can probably put together an outline plan for you in the next week or so. 

A blanket caching of all pages may have unintended consequences, particularly for any interactive parts of the site, and would probably not be advisable.

Danny,

We will discuss here with Dom & Russ and arrange to have a proper discussion with you about this.

Unsure, as you’ve included the email about the images whether your comment is about the cache control for the home page (which we want to cache now) or the image caching problem, but no matter – we’ll catch up with you about both issues.

Regards,
Kirsten

They are two separate issues.

Image caching is happening in the Apache configuration files and amending these should be relatively simple. We have commented on this here: http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/6953.

Page caching (including the home page) is happening at the application level and introducing caching without producing unwanted side effects will require some thought.

Just had a conference call. We have been given the go ahead to investigate what would be required to remove the cache controls from the headers of london2012.com pages, starting with the home page. Estimate: 3 days to investigate, report back and remove caching from the home page.
Set to pending. Attached document already sent to Russ.

Regards,
Kirsten
Marking as solved.

Thanks,

Tom

Hope you had a nice weekend.

Us CRM folk have been thinking about updating the initial sign up page to the e-newsletters on the website. This page: https://www.london2012.com/settings/esignup.php

Actually for that url (as it's XML) the BBC will need to make sure their RSS Feed software is including "application/xhtml+xml,application/xml" in the accepts header.

But if this is some off the shelf desktop app, as Darren says, ITS will need to know the IP address the requests come from (or maybe the user agent of the application they are using) so he can add an exception to the WAF firewall.

Hi Liz,

This should be fine, 

We'll up the limit (to the max) and add an API for the French articles and check everything is still working

We did alter some stuff re. ownership of blog comments (as we have now dropped the UMS tables from our DB) so we'll need to modify that, but that's nothing too crazy.

Re. Performance, I think we should be fine, the issue is unlikely to be the load on the top level API's calls below (as these just list the pages to retrieve) but rather the subsequent requests for the complete pages (*). It would probably be preferable (ie. easier on the CMS) if those subsequent API requests were made sequentially, rather than in parallel. 

Have D3 already run a test with the smaller subsets below ie. pulled back the list of 50 pages and then made an API call for each of them? 

It would also be good to have some visibility on when D3 expect to retrieve the pages so that can check the CMS load at that point.

Jamie

(*) the API calls below just list the names and paths (and some top level info) for all the pages in the CMS, they do not contain the actual content for pages, this need to be retrieved separately via an additional API call.

Fab, thanks Jamie. I’ll pass on the sequential v. Parallel point.

And yes, given that 50 test articles and photos appeared in the D3 CMS a few weeks back, I think they did it all (and obviously without you even noticing ☺)

I’ll try to get them to let me know when they plan on doing the migration – I know broadly ‘next week’...

"given that 50 test articles and photos appeared in the D3 CMS a few weeks back, I think they did it all (and obviously without you even noticing ☺)"

Excellent... that was my line of thinking (ie. if the loaded them and we didn't notice)... although thinking back..... ;-) 

In all seriousness, I can't remember us being hit with any load issues in the past few weeks, still it would be good to be aware when D3 do it this time as the volumes are likely to be higher.
PS Jamie, how many days' effort shall we ask for the PO? (excluding the 3 days we have already claimed)

I think so.. as you say, let us know when your planning to do this as some questions are bound to pop up and it would be good to be around so that you can get them answered quickly.

Jamie

Hi Michael,

You can't delete a webcam in the CMS, it will just re-appear when the feed next runs (the way the feed is setup it checks to see if the webcam exists and if not creates - or in this case - recreates it).

Michael

Yes, thats a resizing of the image..

Althoguh we delete the page the image is still there, will look at removing it, but do be aware that (by default) removing a page doesn't expire an image used on it (so if someone knows the url they can get to the image.

I normal circumstances the image wont' be referenced - even in google - if there is no page on the site referencing it. I expect in the case of webcams people have been direct linking to the image).

I will remove it manually now.

Jamie

Great thanks very much

Just removed it, although (just to confuse matters!!) unlike the English webcam pages you can actually delete the French webcam pages in the CMS / browse interface.

* the reason being is that the French webcam pages get created by a manual translation process / workflow and not by the webcam feed directly (so unless they are re-sent for translation they won't appear, and if the original english page has been removed, they can't be re-sent for translation).
Sounds good, thanks very much
